title: Headache, Unspecified
scope: ** Empiric treatment-focused management of undifferentiated or unspecified headache when the diagnosis is unclear, pending further evaluation, or does not fit a specific headache category. Emphasizes acute headache management in the ED and hospital (parenteral headache cocktail: ketorolac, metoclopramide, diphenhydramine, dexamethasone), empiric abortive treatment, and outpatient follow-up planning. Applies when the patient presents with headache and a definitive primary or secondary headache diagnosis has not yet been established. Differs from the Headache Evaluation plan, which focuses on the diagnostic workup algorithm. Excludes thunderclap headache (separate protocol), confirmed secondary headaches (SAH, meningitis, mass lesion), and specific primary headache disorders once diagnosed (migraine, tension-type, cluster -- see dedicated plans).

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Rule out anemia, infection, leukocytosis as headache contributor
Electrolyte abnormalities, renal function for NSAID safety
Pregnancy status affects treatment selection (avoid NSAIDs in 3rd trimester, avoid ergotamines)
Low magnesium associated with headache disorders; guides supplementation

Extended Workup.rationale: Hepatic function for acetaminophen safety; glucose for hypoglycemia
Thyroid dysfunction can cause chronic headache
Rule out GCA if age >50 with new-onset headache; inflammatory cause
Deficiency associated with chronic headache frequency

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Suspected autoimmune/vasculitis cause in atypical presentations
Endemic areas with refractory or subacute headache

Essential/First-line.timing: Any red flag: thunderclap onset, worst headache of life, focal deficits, altered mental status, anticoagulation, age >50 new onset
Essential/First-line.target: No hemorrhage, mass, hydrocephalus, or midline shift

Essential/First-line.timing: Recurrent/chronic unspecified headache, abnormal neurological exam, refractory to treatment

Extended.timing: Suspected mass, infection, or inflammation; abnormal non-contrast MRI
Extended.target: No enhancement, mass, or meningeal disease
Normal vasculature; no aneurysm or dissection

Extended.timing: Suspected cerebral venous thrombosis (headache with papilledema, seizure, postpartum)
Suspected dissection, aneurysm, or vasculopathy when MRA unavailable
Baseline before metoclopramide or prochlorperazine (QTc assessment)

Rare/Specialized.timing: Suspected SAH with negative CT, suspected meningitis, suspected IIH
Rare/Specialized.target: Normal OP (10-20 cm H2O); clear CSF; WBC <5; protein 15-45; glucose >60% serum
Rare/Specialized.contraindications: Coagulopathy, mass lesion with risk of herniation

Rare/Specialized.target: Normal cervical alignment; no disc herniation

ED Empiric Headache Cocktail (First-Line.indication: Dehydration commonly accompanies headache; empiric rehydration

doseOptions.orderSentence: IV normal saline bolus (CPT 96360) 500-1000 mL IV

dosing.instructions: NS or LR 500-1000 mL IV bolus over 30-60 min
dosing.orderSentence: IV normal saline bolus (CPT 96360) 500-1000 mL IV

ED Empiric Headache Cocktail (First-Line.indication: First-line NSAID for acute headache in ED; effective regardless of headache subtype

dosing.instructions: 30 mg IV push (15 mg if age >65, CrCl <50, or weight <50 kg); max 5 days total NSAID use

ED Empiric Headache Cocktail (First-Line.contraindications: Renal impairment (CrCl <30); active GI bleed; aspirin/NSAID allergy; third trimester pregnancy; anticoagulation with high bleed risk
ED Empiric Headache Cocktail (First-Line.monitoring: Renal function if repeated dosing; GI symptoms

ED Empiric Headache Cocktail (First-Line.indication: First-line NSAID for acute headache when IV access unavailable

dosing.instructions: 60 mg IM once (30 mg if age >65, CrCl <50, or weight <50 kg); max 5 days total NSAID use

ED Empiric Headache Cocktail (First-Line.contraindications: Renal impairment (CrCl <30); active GI bleed; aspirin/NSAID allergy; third trimester pregnancy; anticoagulation with high bleed risk
ED Empiric Headache Cocktail (First-Line.monitoring: Renal function if repeated dosing; GI symptoms

ED Empiric Headache Cocktail (First-Line.indication: Anti-headache properties independent of anti-emetic effect; dopamine antagonist effective for undifferentiated headache

dosing.instructions: 10 mg IV over 15 min; repeat once in 30 min if needed; always co-administer diphenhydramine to prevent akathisia

ED Empiric Headache Cocktail (First-Line.contraindications: Parkinson's disease; tardive dyskinesia history; bowel obstruction; pheochromocytoma; QTc >500 ms

ED Empiric Headache Cocktail (First-Line.indication: Prevents akathisia from dopamine antagonists; mild analgesic adjunct

dosing.instructions: 25 mg IV push prior to or with metoclopramide

ED Empiric Headache Cocktail (First-Line.contraindications: Narrow-angle glaucoma; urinary retention; severe sedation risk (elderly)

ED Empiric Headache Cocktail (First-Line.indication: Reduces 24-72h headache recurrence; recommended adjunct to ED headache cocktail

dosing.instructions: 10 mg IV push once (single dose)

ED Empiric Headache Cocktail (First-Line.contraindications: Active untreated infection; uncontrolled diabetes (relative -- still give, monitor glucose)

ED Empiric Headache Cocktail - Alternati.indication: Alternative to metoclopramide; preferred if stronger anti-emetic effect needed

dosing.instructions: 10 mg IV slow push over 5-10 min; co-administer diphenhydramine 25 mg IV

ED Empiric Headache Cocktail - Alternati.contraindications: Parkinson's disease; QT prolongation; severe hypotension; CNS depression

ED Empiric Headache Cocktail - Alternati.indication: Second-line dopamine antagonist; effective for refractory acute headache

dosing.instructions: 12.5 mg IV in 500 mL NS over 20 min; repeat 25 mg in 30 min if needed; co-administer diphenhydramine

ED Empiric Headache Cocktail - Alternati.contraindications: QT prolongation; severe hepatic disease; Parkinson's disease; CNS depression

Second-Line Parenteral (Refractory to Co.indication: Adjunct for refractory headache; particularly effective if low magnesium or suspected migraine

dosing.instructions: 2 g IV in 100 mL NS over 20-30 min

Second-Line Parenteral (Refractory to Co.contraindications: Renal failure (GFR <30); myasthenia gravis; heart block
Second-Line Parenteral (Refractory to Co.monitoring: Mg levels, patellar reflexes, respiratory rate

Second-Line Parenteral (Refractory to Co.indication: Refractory headache unresponsive to cocktail; broad-spectrum headache efficacy

dosing.instructions: 500-1000 mg IV over 15-30 min

Second-Line Parenteral (Refractory to Co.contraindications: Pregnancy; hepatic disease; mitochondrial disease (POLG mutation); pancreatitis history

Second-Line Parenteral (Refractory to Co.indication: Alternative if NSAIDs contraindicated; NSAID allergy, renal impairment, GI bleed risk

dosing.instructions: 1000 mg IV over 15 min; max 3000 mg/day from all sources

Second-Line Parenteral (Refractory to Co.contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment (ALT >3x ULN); chronic alcohol use (>3 drinks/day)
Second-Line Parenteral (Refractory to Co.monitoring: LFTs if repeated dosing; total daily dose from all acetaminophen sources

Second-Line Parenteral (Refractory to Co.indication: Suspected migraine with uncertain diagnosis; test dose is diagnostic and therapeutic

dosing.instructions: 6 mg SC once; repeat in 2h if partial response; max 12 mg/24h

Second-Line Parenteral (Refractory to Co.contraindications: CAD, prior stroke/TIA, uncontrolled HTN, hemiplegic migraine features, pregnancy (relative), triptan within 24h, ergot within 24h

Second-Line Parenteral (Refractory to Co.indication: Refractory headache; occipital-predominant pain; avoids systemic medications

dosing.instructions: 2-3 mL 2% lidocaine (or 0.25% bupivacaine) with or without 40 mg triamcinolone at greater occipital nerve bilaterally

Second-Line Parenteral (Refractory to Co.contraindications: Local anesthetic allergy; infection at injection site
Second-Line Parenteral (Refractory to Co.monitoring: Immediate pain response; vasovagal reaction; local bruising

Oral/Outpatient Acute Treatment.indication: First-line oral analgesic for mild-moderate headache

dosing.instructions: 400-800 mg PO at onset; repeat q6-8h; max 2400 mg/day; limit to <15 days/month

Oral/Outpatient Acute Treatment.contraindications: Renal impairment; GI bleed history; aspirin allergy; third trimester pregnancy
Oral/Outpatient Acute Treatment.monitoring: GI symptoms; renal function if prolonged

Oral/Outpatient Acute Treatment.indication: First-line oral NSAID; longer duration of action than ibuprofen

dosing.instructions: 500-550 mg PO at onset; repeat 250 mg in 12h if needed; max 1250 mg/day; limit to <15 days/month

Oral/Outpatient Acute Treatment.contraindications: Renal impairment; GI bleed history; aspirin allergy; third trimester pregnancy
Oral/Outpatient Acute Treatment.monitoring: GI symptoms; renal function if prolonged

Oral/Outpatient Acute Treatment.indication: First-line if NSAID contraindicated; mild-moderate headache

dosing.instructions: 1000 mg PO at onset; repeat q6h; max 3000 mg/day (2000 mg if liver disease); limit to <15 days/month

Oral/Outpatient Acute Treatment.contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment; chronic heavy alcohol use
Oral/Outpatient Acute Treatment.monitoring: LFTs if chronic use; total daily dose from all sources

Oral/Outpatient Acute Treatment.indication: First-line oral analgesic; anti-inflammatory and anti-platelet

dosing.instructions: 650-1000 mg PO at onset; max 4000 mg/day; limit to <15 days/month

Oral/Outpatient Acute Treatment.contraindications: Bleeding disorders; GI ulcer; aspirin allergy; children/teens (Reye syndrome); third trimester

Oral/Outpatient Acute Treatment.indication: Combination analgesic with caffeine adjunct; enhanced efficacy

dosing.instructions: 2 tablets PO at onset (acetaminophen 250 mg + aspirin 250 mg + caffeine 65 mg per tablet); max 2 doses/24h

Oral/Outpatient Acute Treatment.contraindications: Per component contraindications (hepatic impairment, GI bleed, aspirin allergy, bleeding disorders)
Oral/Outpatient Acute Treatment.monitoring: Risk of MOH with frequent use; limit to <10 days/month

Oral/Outpatient Acute Treatment.indication: Nausea with headache; has independent anti-headache properties

dosing.instructions: 10 mg PO at headache onset; repeat in 8h if needed; max 30 mg/day

Oral/Outpatient Acute Treatment.monitoring: Akathisia; limit to <12 weeks continuous use

Pregnancy-Safe Options.indication: First-line oral analgesic in pregnancy for any headache

dosing.instructions: 1000 mg PO q6h; max 3000 mg/day

Pregnancy-Safe Options.indication: First-line parenteral analgesic in pregnancy when oral not tolerated

dosing.instructions: 1000 mg IV over 15 min q6h; max 3000 mg/day

Pregnancy-Safe Options.indication: Safe in pregnancy; anti-headache and anti-emetic

dosing.instructions: 10 mg IV q8h

Pregnancy-Safe Options.indication: Safe in pregnancy; anti-headache and anti-emetic for outpatient use

dosing.instructions: 10 mg PO q8h

Pregnancy-Safe Options.indication: Anti-emetic adjunct; caution in first trimester

dosing.instructions: 4 mg IV q8h

Pregnancy-Safe Options.contraindications: QT prolongation; first trimester (relative -- limited data)

Pregnancy-Safe Options.indication: Anti-emetic adjunct for outpatient use; caution in first trimester

dosing.instructions: 4 mg PO q8h

Pregnancy-Safe Options.contraindications: QT prolongation; first trimester (relative -- limited data)

Pregnancy-Safe Options.indication: Adjunct for headache in pregnancy; also seizure prophylaxis benefit

dosing.instructions: 2 g IV over 20-30 min

doseOptions.orderSentence: Occipital nerve block - lidocaine (CPT 64405) 2-3 mL SC

dosing.instructions: 2% lidocaine 2-3 mL per side at greater occipital nerve
dosing.orderSentence: Occipital nerve block - lidocaine (CPT 64405) 2-3 mL SC

Empiric Outpatient Bridging (Discharge f.indication: Bridge therapy for recurrent headache pending outpatient evaluation

dosing.instructions: 500 mg PO BID with food for 5-7 days; then PRN

Empiric Outpatient Bridging (Discharge f.contraindications: Renal impairment; GI bleed; aspirin allergy; 3rd trimester pregnancy

Empiric Outpatient Bridging (Discharge f.indication: Prevent headache recurrence after ED discharge; bridging for refractory cases

dosing.instructions: 4 mg PO BID x 2 days, then 4 mg daily x 2 days, then stop

Empiric Outpatient Bridging (Discharge f.indication: Rescue therapy at home for recurrent nausea/headache

dosing.instructions: 25 mg PR q12h PRN; max 3 days

Empiric Outpatient Bridging (Discharge f.indication: Anti-emetic rescue for nausea/vomiting with headache recurrence

dosing.instructions: 4 mg ODT q8h PRN

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology consult if headache refractory to ED cocktail (>2 rounds) or atypical features present
Headache specialist/Neurology outpatient referral for recurrent unspecified headache requiring classification
Ophthalmology/Fundoscopy if papilledema suspected or visual symptoms present
Physical therapy referral for cervicogenic or musculoskeletal component
Behavioral health/Psychology referral for comorbid anxiety, depression, or stress-related headache triggers
Dentistry/TMJ specialist if jaw pain, bruxism, or temporomandibular dysfunction contributing
Sleep medicine evaluation for insomnia or sleep apnea contributing to chronic headache

Patient Instructions.item: Return immediately for sudden severe headache ("worst headache of life") which indicates possible hemorrhage
Return immediately for headache with fever, stiff neck, or altered mental status which indicates possible infection
Return if new neurological symptoms develop (weakness, numbness, vision changes, speech difficulty, seizure)
Keep headache diary tracking frequency, severity, duration, triggers, and medications to guide follow-up classification
Limit acute pain medication use to no more than 10-15 days per month to prevent medication overuse headache
Take acute medications early at headache onset for best efficacy rather than waiting for severe pain
Follow up with PCP or neurologist within 2-4 weeks for headache classification and preventive planning
Bring completed headache diary to follow-up appointment to aid diagnosis

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Maintain regular sleep schedule (7-8 hours, consistent bedtime and wake time)
Stay well-hydrated (at least 64 oz water daily) as dehydration commonly triggers headache
Perform regular aerobic exercise (30 minutes moderate activity 5 times/week) to reduce headache frequency
Practice stress management (relaxation techniques, mindfulness, progressive muscle relaxation)
Identify and avoid personal triggers (alcohol, certain foods, weather changes, bright lights, strong smells)
Limit caffeine to moderate consistent intake (less than 200 mg/day) to prevent withdrawal headaches
Eat regular meals; do not skip meals as fasting commonly triggers headache
Complete ergonomic workspace assessment to reduce neck/shoulder strain for office workers
Limit screen time and take regular breaks (20-20-20 rule: every 20 minutes, look 20 feet away for 20 seconds)

differential.features: Unilateral, pulsating, moderate-severe intensity; nausea/vomiting; photo AND phonophobia; aggravated by physical activity; lasts 4-72h
differential.tests: Clinical criteria (ICHD-3); response to triptans diagnostic

differential.features: Bilateral, pressing/tightening (non-pulsating), mild-moderate intensity; no nausea/vomiting; not worsened by activity
differential.tests: Clinical criteria (ICHD-3); no photophobia AND phonophobia together

differential.features: Strictly unilateral, periorbital, excruciating; ipsilateral autonomic features (tearing, rhinorrhea, ptosis, miosis); 15-180 min; circadian pattern
Chronic daily headache (>15 days/month); regular analgesic use >10-15 days/month for >3 months
differential.tests: Detailed medication diary; improves with overuse medication withdrawal

differential.features: Thunderclap onset (maximal in seconds); "worst headache of life"; neck stiffness; altered mental status
differential.tests: CT head (sensitivity ~95% at 6h); LP for xanthochromia if CT negative

differential.features: Fever, neck stiffness, photophobia, altered mental status; subacute to acute onset
differential.tests: LP (cell count, protein, glucose, culture); blood cultures

differential.features: Positional (worse lying flat); papilledema; pulsatile tinnitus; visual obscurations; often obese young women
differential.tests: LP with opening pressure >25 cm H2O; MRI/MRV normal

differential.features: Age >50; new headache type; scalp tenderness; jaw claudication; visual symptoms; polymyalgia
differential.tests: ESR/CRP markedly elevated; temporal artery biopsy

differential.features: Unilateral, starts in neck, radiates frontally; triggered by neck movement or sustained posture; reduced cervical ROM
differential.tests: Physical exam (decreased ROM, tenderness); diagnostic nerve block

differential.features: Progressive headache; seizures; focal deficits; risk factors (pregnancy, OCP, thrombophilia)
Progressive headache; worse in morning or with Valsalva; focal neurological signs; papilledema
Sudden severe unilateral headache/neck pain; ipsilateral Horner syndrome possible; history of trauma or neck manipulation
Severely elevated BP (>180/120); headache with encephalopathy, visual changes, end-organ damage
differential.tests: BP measurement; fundoscopy; renal function; urinalysis

evidence.recommendation: Metoclopramide effective for acute undifferentiated headache in ED
Prochlorperazine superior to placebo for acute headache
Ketorolac effective for acute headache in ED
Dexamethasone single dose reduces headache recurrence at 24-72h
Diphenhydramine prevents akathisia from dopamine antagonists
Combination parenteral therapy (cocktail) more effective than single agents
IV magnesium sulfate as adjunct for acute headache
ICHD-3 classification criteria for headache disorders
SNNOOP10 red flags for secondary headache screening
IV valproate for refractory acute headache
Occipital nerve block for refractory headache in ED
Simple analgesics (acetaminophen, NSAIDs) for acute headache
MOH prevalence and prevention with acute medication limits
Sumatriptan SC for acute headache with suspected migraine

monitoring.frequency: q30 min in ED; q4h inpatient; each visit OPD
monitoring.action: Escalate treatment per algorithm (cocktail -> second-line -> nerve block)

monitoring.frequency: q30 min in ED during treatment; q4h inpatient
monitoring.action: Address fever (infection workup); treat hypertension; tachycardia indicates pain

monitoring.frequency: q1h in ED; q4-8h inpatient; each visit OPD
monitoring.action: Any new deficit: urgent imaging; neurology consult
QTc >500 ms: avoid dopamine antagonists; use alternative

monitoring.frequency: Continuous at home; review each visit
monitoring.action: Refer to neurology/headache specialist for classification and prevention

monitoring.item: Acute medication use days per month
monitoring.action: Counsel on MOH risk; initiate prevention; refer if MOH established

monitoring.frequency: After 2+ doses ketorolac; if renal risk factors

disposition.criteria: Pain controlled (NRS <4); able to tolerate PO; no red flags on history/exam/imaging; ambulatory; close follow-up arranged (PCP or neurology 2-4 weeks); MOH counseling provided; headache diary instructions given; return precautions reviewed

Headache refractory to 2 rounds of ED cocktail; unable to tolerate PO; severe dehydration requiring prolonged IV fluids; pending further workup for red flag features; concern for secondary headache requiring LP or serial imaging
Rare for primary headache; indicated if suspected secondary cause with hemodynamic instability, altered mental status, or evolving neurological deficits pending workup
Within 2-4 weeks for recurrent unspecified headache requiring formal classification; sooner (1-2 weeks) if frequent (>4 headache days/month) or disabling
Within 1-2 weeks after ED visit for first-time headache; reassess response to acute treatment; determine if prevention needed
